event.title: 1856, most of the remaining natives were moved

data.event: Following the Rogue River Indian War in 1856, most of the remaining natives were moved by the government to the Grand Ronde Indian Reservation.
However, seven families of Umpqua hid in the hills, eluding capture for many decades.
They are now federally recognized as the Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians.
Douglas County was created on January 7, 1852, from the portion of Umpqua County which lay east of the Coast Range summit.
In 1856 the Camas Valley was annexed to Douglas County from Coos County.

event.title: 1862, the rest of Umpqua county was absorbed

data.event: In 1862, the rest of Umpqua county was absorbed into Douglas County, some say due to the loss of population following the end of the early gold boom, while others attribute the absorption to politics.

event.title: were made with Jackson and Lane Counties in 1915

data.event: Further boundary adjustments were made with Jackson and Lane Counties in 1915.
